content: The Act may be cited as the "Railroad Unemployment Insurance Amendments Act of 1996". It includes a waiting period for unemployment benefits. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is amended to include a waiting period for unemployment benefits, with benefits payable to qualified employees for each day of unemployment in excess of 4 during any registration period within a period of continuing unemployment. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act now includes a waiting period for benefits, with payments for each day of unemployment exceeding 7 during the first registration period in a period of continuing unemployment. Additionally, a 14-day waiting period applies if a strike causes unemployment during a period of continuing unemployment. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act includes a waiting period for benefits, with a 14-day waiting period for strikes causing unemployment during a period of continuing unemployment. No benefits are payable for the first 14 days of unemployment due to a strike, with subsequent days of unemployment eligible for benefits. The term 'period of continuing unemployment' refers to a single registration period or a series of consecutive registration periods, each including more than 4 days of unemployment. The term 'period of continuing unemployment' is defined as a single registration period with more than 4 days of unemployment, a series of consecutive registration periods with each having more than 4 days of unemployment, or a series of successive registration periods with each having more than 4 days of unemployment where each succeeding period starts within 15 days of the previous one. The succeeding registration period begins within 15 days after the last day of the immediately preceding registration period. A period of continuing unemployment ends when an employee exhausts rights to unemployment benefits. No benefits are payable if the total remuneration exceeds the amount for the registration period. An eligible employee may not receive benefits if their total remuneration in a registration period exceeds the base year monthly compensation base. Remuneration includes any potential earnings that were not received because the employee was not available for work. SEC. 3. WAITING PERIOD FOR SICKNESS BENEFITS. A period of continuing sickness is defined as a series of consecutive sick days from one or more causes, or successive sick days from a single cause with no interruption of more than 90 days that are not sick days. A period of continuing sickness is defined as a series of consecutive sick days from one or more causes, or successive sick days from a single cause with no interruption of more than 90 days that are not sick days. A special rule applies for the end of the sickness period when an employee exhausts sickness benefits. SEC. 4. MAXIMUM DAILY BENEFIT RATE. The maximum daily benefit rate is calculated based on the monthly compensation base from the previous year, multiplied by 5 percent and rounded down to the nearest dollar. SEC. 5. MAXIMUM NUMBER OF DAYS FOR BENEFITS. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is amended to set the maximum number of days for benefits at 130 for both unemployment and sickness within a benefit year. The Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act limits benefits to 130 days for both unemployment and sickness within a benefit year, with the total amount not exceeding the employee's compensation in the base year. Extended unemployment benefits or extended sickness benefits may be paid for up to 65 days to individuals who did not voluntarily leave work without good cause and have exhausted their normal benefit rights in a benefit year. The benefit year will be extended until the last day of the extended benefit period. Extended unemployment or sickness benefits can be paid for up to 65 days after exhausting normal benefit rights, starting from the first day of unemployment or sickness. The extended benefit period for unemployment or sickness begins on the first day after exhausting normal benefits and lasts for 7 consecutive 14-day periods, not exceeding the start of a new benefit year when the employee qualifies for benefits again. The extended benefit period for sickness benefits extends beyond the first registration period in a benefit year when the employee qualifies for benefits again. However, the period terminates when the employee reaches age 65, except for paying benefits for days of unemployment. The Railroad Retirement Act of 1974 provides benefits for employees with 14 or more consecutive days of unemployment or sickness who will be qualified for benefits in the next benefit year. Section 2(h) of the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act is repealed, and Section 17 of the Railroad is also repealed. Repeal of Deadwood Provision in the Railroad Unemployment Insurance Act and repeal of expired provision related to supplemental unemployment benefits. The amendments made by this Act will be effective on the date of enactment.
